citations.narrative:
There are structural problems in several areas of the facility.
- The enclosure fence housing sheep, goats, and emus has loose strands of barbed wire along the section of fence
bordering the road. This is a potential source of injury and/or entrapment to the enclosed animals.
- The sheep/goat/emu fence itself is sagging in several places, most notably behind the pond in the rear of the facility. The
fence also has multiple gaps between the wire and the ground. The fence must be maintained in good condition to help
contain the enclosed animals, and to prevent outside animals from gaining access to the enclosure.
- There are exposed wire ground panels in several pens. Some of the wire has curled or sharp edges, and other sections
have developed holes in the ground underneath the wire. This is a potential source of injury and/or entrapment to the
enclosed animals. The exposed sheets of ground wire must be reburied or repaired to protect the welfare of the animals.
- There are sharp points and edges in several areas of the facility. These include nail heads in wooden pallets in several
pens, exposed nail heads in the sheep/goat main pen, and sharp rusted edges along the bottom of the metal barn in the
goat/yak enclosure. Sharp points and edges are a potential source on injury, and must be removed or repaired.
All affected areas must be repaired or replaced by 15 August 2024.

Several shelters in different parts of the facility were in a state of disrepair.
- The roof of the wooden shelter in the mara pen is damaged and detaching from the support walls. This is a potential
source of injury to the enclosed animals, and this structure should be repaired or replaced.
- The roof of the barn in the goat/yak enclosure is in very poor condition. Multiple wooden beams are partially detached
and hanging into the enclosure. A section of sheet metal is also hanging in the enclosure. This area of the roof is largely
an open space and does not provide shade or shelter to any animals underneath it. This entire portion of the roof must be
repaired or replaced to ensure the safety of the animals, and to provide adequate shelter from the elements.
- Part of the roof in the deer enclosure is damaged and open to the air, with a section of plywood loosely attached and
hanging over the interior of the shelter. This is a potential source of injury to the deer, and also makes the shelter
ineffective at protecting the animals from the elements. The roof must be repaired and maintained appropriately.
All shelter repairs must be completed no later than 15 August 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
There are structural problems in several areas of the facility. 
- The enclosure fence housing sheep, goats, and emus has loose strands of barbed wire along the section of fence 
bordering the road. This is a potential source of injury and/or entrapment to the enclosed animals.  
- The sheep/goat/emu fence itself is sagging in several places, most notably behind the pond in the rear of the facility. The 
fence also has multiple gaps between the wire and the ground. The fence must be maintained in good condition to help 
contain the enclosed animals, and to prevent outside animals from gaining access to the enclosure. 
- There are exposed wire ground panels in several pens. Some of the wire has curled or sharp edges, and other sections 
have developed holes in the ground underneath the wire. This is a potential source of injury and/or entrapment to the 
enclosed animals. The exposed sheets of ground wire must be reburied or repaired to protect the welfare of the animals. 
- There are sharp points and edges in several areas of the facility. These include nail heads in wooden pallets in several 
pens, exposed nail heads in the sheep/goat main pen, and sharp rusted edges along the bottom of the metal barn in the 
goat/yak enclosure. Sharp points and edges are a potential source on injury, and must be removed or repaired. 
All affected areas must be repaired or replaced by 15 August 2024. 
3.127(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Several shelters in different parts of the facility were in a state of disrepair. 
- The roof of the wooden shelter in the mara pen is damaged and detaching from the support walls. This is a potential 
source of injury to the enclosed animals, and this structure should be repaired or replaced. 
- The roof of the barn in the goat/yak enclosure is in very poor condition. Multiple wooden beams are partially detached 
and hanging into the enclosure. A section of sheet metal is also hanging in the enclosure. This area of the roof is largely 
an open space and does not provide shade or shelter to any animals underneath it. This entire portion of the roof must be 
repaired or replaced to ensure the safety of the animals, and to provide adequate shelter from the elements. 
- Part of the roof in the deer enclosure is damaged and open to the air, with a section of plywood loosely attached and 
hanging over the interior of the shelter. This is a potential source of injury to the deer, and also makes the shelter 
ineffective at protecting the animals from the elements. The roof must be repaired and maintained appropriately. 
All shelter repairs must be completed no later than 15 August 2024.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee. 
 
 n
